verses.text: Wisdom stretches from one end to the other mightily, and gracefully governs all things.
verses.comment: Here Wisdom is depicted as universally active and sovereign, consistent with the tradition that sees Wisdom as both creative and sustaining (see Proverbs 3:19). Early Christian writers saw this as a foreshadowing of Christ's role in creation (John 1:1-3), linking Wisdom and the Word.

verses.text: I loved her and sought her from my youth; I desired to make her my bride and was captivated by her beauty.
verses.comment: Wisdom here is personified as a beloved, connecting with the idea of spiritual pursuit and devotion—parallels exist in how the New Testament speaks of Christ as the Bridegroom (Matt. 9:15).

verses.text: She glorifies her noble origin by living with God, and the Lord of all loves her.
verses.comment: Wisdom is portrayed as dwelling with God, reminiscent of the Logos theology in John 1:1. Her relationship with God foreshadows the union of Christ with the Father.

verses.text: She is initiated into the knowledge of God's works and chooses what is good in his eyes.
verses.comment: Wisdom's participation in divine works echoes the principle that true knowledge comes from God—a foundation for understanding divine inspiration and guidance.

verses.text: If riches are a desirable possession in life, what is richer than Wisdom, who works everything?
verses.comment: The text elevates Wisdom above material wealth—reflecting Jesus’ own teaching on the greater value of the kingdom of heaven (Matt. 6:33).

verses.text: If understanding effects, who among men is more a craftsman than she?
verses.comment: Here, Wisdom’s creative power is emphasized, paralleling the idea of Christ as the agent of creation (Col. 1:16).

verses.text: If anyone loves righteousness, her labors are virtues; she teaches temperance, prudence, justice, and courage—nothing in life is more useful to mankind than these.
verses.comment: The four virtues listed later became foundational in Christian ethics—pointing toward a life transformed by grace, as also highlighted in Paul's letters.

verses.text: If one desires wide experience, she knows things past, predicts things to come, penetrates the subtleties of words and solves riddles—she can foresee signs and wonders and the progression of times and seasons.
verses.comment: Wisdom’s knowledge of mysteries relates to prophecy and discernment—spiritual gifts given to the faithful, seen throughout the Scriptures (see Daniel 2:21-22).

verses.text: Therefore, I resolved to take her as my companion in life, knowing that she will be my counselor for good and bring comfort in cares and sorrow.
verses.comment: Taking Wisdom as a lifelong companion reflects the call to continuous spiritual growth and guidance by divine truth (James 1:5).

verses.text: Because of her, I will have honor among the people and, though young, be held in esteem for my judgment.
verses.comment: Divine Wisdom bestows true honor—aligning with the biblical principle that leadership and responsibility come from God’s favor, not merely age or status.

verses.text: I will be admired before rulers; and be marveled at when they see me.
verses.comment: Wisdom gives confidence before the powerful, reminiscent of Joseph and Daniel’s rise in foreign courts through God-given insight.

verses.text: When I am silent, they will wait for me; when I speak, they will give heed; and, while discussing, they will fix their gaze upon me.
verses.comment: Wisdom draws respect and authority, echoing the way Christ spoke with authority and people listened (Luke 4:32).

verses.text: By her, I will possess immortality and leave an everlasting memory to those after me.
verses.comment: Here, immortality signifies not only lasting legacy but hints at an afterlife—foreshadowing Christian doctrine of resurrection and eternal life.

verses.text: I will rule nations and peoples will be subject to me.
verses.comment: A messianic undertone echoes here, similar to Psalm 2:8, which many interpret as prophecy fulfilled in Jesus Christ's universal kingship.

verses.text: Dreadful tyrants will be afraid when they hear of me; among the people, I will be admired in the midst of rulers.
verses.comment: Wisdom confers authority, even over adversaries. Christians have understood this as the spiritual authority possessed by the saints and apostles.

verses.text: Through her, I will become virtuous, and in war, I will show courage; returning home, I will find rest with her, for her companionship never brings bitterness or grief but only joy and gladness.
verses.comment: Virtue and inner peace—signs of Wisdom—reflect the fruit of the Spirit (Gal. 5:22-23). The Christian life is marked by both struggle and consolation.

verses.text: Reflecting on these things within myself, I understood that being joined to Wisdom leads to immortality.
verses.comment: The connection of Wisdom with immortality points to the promise of eternal life in Christ — both literally and spiritually.

verses.text: Love of her brings honor; possessing her brings security in words of good repute; she grants friendship with God and approval from the Lord.
verses.comment: Wisdom brings us into communion with God. Christ calls believers friends and invites them into deeper intimacy and the assurance found in true faith.

verses.text: Therefore, I prayed to the Lord and entreated him, saying with all my heart:
verses.comment: The earnest prayer for Wisdom marks humility and reliance on divine grace, aligning with James 1:5 where God gives wisdom generously.

verses.text: "From childhood, I was blessed with a good soul, or rather, being good, I entered into an undefiled body."
verses.comment: The idea of a good soul and purity from youth echoes the biblical theme that God’s grace can be at work even before one’s conscious choosing (Jer. 1:5).

verses.text: But understanding that I could not possess Wisdom unless God gave her to me—and this itself was a mark of wisdom—I turned to the Lord and begged him, earnestly praying for her.
verses.comment: True wisdom is known as a gift from God, not mere human effort. Seeking divine guidance and grace is foundational, paralleling the faith that relies on God’s initiative in salvation and spiritual growth.
